content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
												Counter-Strike: Condition Zero is the first official sequel to mod Counter-Strike, released in retail in 2004. It was pretty much same Counter-Strike on same engine and minimal changes when it comes to multiplayer experience, but it had more to often to solo players, with addition of bots and "Deleted Scenes" pack of single-player missions.Now, for multiplayer community... Is as good as ever. While it's not on the level of Counter-Strike 1.6, you will still be able to find few almost-full servers, whetever it's yet another De_Dust2 map or some server that actually rotates maps. Just more smaller tighter community. BUT it's kinda way too high-skilled by now for newbies to be able to enter in easily.So, when it comes to the main, expected, multiplayer part of the game, it didn't recieve many changes. Explosive grenades are stronger. Hostages are a bit more realistical. The end.Oh, and you will ntoice that graphics got a small boost, as far as HL1 engine goes ("GldSrc"). Models got more detail to them. Few tweaks here and there. Maps are much interesting as far as graphical design goes. If you are going to play de_dust2 non-stop then better do it at the less bland one.And yes, I don't really like Counter-Strike realistical gameplay much here either.Now, for single-player, you finally get some bots to play with. Which are less frustating for new people than online play and helps to hone aiming skills as well better. Though, while they navigate through default maps quite nicely, they don't always make best decision. As a protip, always send them a voice command to stick together, team. They also try not to steal your fun of defusing bomb, waiting for commander to do it, even if said commander is in opposite end of map. Yes, it's a flaw.And like Quake 3 Arena and UT, CZ single player consist of repeated matches with bots, as you will progress through trio of maps, being able to pick less and less stupid teammates over time, always being on side of Counter-Terrorists. And on each map, you have to have more than 2 wins over score of Terrorist team and have to complete each of three objectives, which go like "rescue <x> hostages", "kill <x> amount of Terrorists yourself", "finish some round in <x> time" and "kill <x> terrorists with <y> weapon".  So, fun for a while, but more of "just so something was there".And now for Deleted Scenes. This is what Counter-Strike: Condition Zero was supposed to be at some point, a full-blown single-player campaign. It was "cancelled" once Valve saw magazines giving it low ratings to preview, just to have it put along as bonus into final game. All just to get low ratings once again due to being "more of same". Deleted Scenes had 12 missions in retail release, with Steam version adding 6 more that you can select anytime from World Map.Now, Deleted Scene is a mix of good and bad. The excellent level design and repetive core gameplay.First, good things. Level design is quite good one. You will have to take control of unnamed heroes of counter-terrorist operations all over the world, with missions having great variety, with enough lenght to keep you playing, having to stop terrorists from taking over nuke in snowy part of Russia, defending yourself in Arabain town or fighting your way through the jungles. Seriously, some of the missions just have a bit of that scripted hollywood love that would make them worthy of being in Call of Duty and alikes, quite epic! Levels themselves are also build with knowledge of pacing and a bit of exploration, albeit linear.And it really tries to push GldSrc engine! In order to make it look like it's capable of more than expected, developers made a lot of animations of death for terrorists as well as destruction animations. Hell, I was amazed to see a stack of boxes getting squeezed by a door in the third mission, it's all quite joy to look at even if it's scripted. And well, it does hurt occasionally when it comes to enemies deaths. Like, when you shot with pistol at melee enemy into knee and he suddenly teleported half-meter away to the door, swirled and fell toward the door, just to get it open.But core gameplay of Counter-Strike doesn't translate well at all into linear levels of single-player. What you bassicly will do, is to shoot few bullets into heads, while taking some hitscan bullets back. Repeat it on every enemy. Until the end of the game. It really is repetive and boring. Weapons don't matter much, all of them are good enough for bursting enemy again and again. Grenades aren't given often and flashbang don't seem to be as useful as in multiplayer. Smoke grenade is more offensive there though, making enemies cough instead sometimes. There is little enemy variety as well, you just got whatever hitscan stupid enemy, stationary snipers with laser, whatever melee enemy that rushes you and terrorist with freaking bazooka that is pain to avoid too! So, burst headshot, and burst headshot, repeat repeat repeat.It also finally get to have some music there. For once. So, something definitely good.Counter-Strike Condition Zero is better offer than Counter-Strike 1.6 and has more value for solo players, but it's still not good enough to get me much interested in such twitchy realistical shooter. I still wouldn't recommend new people, especially with newer CS titles out there, only those who already play Counter-Strike should check out this one.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												COUNTER STRIKE: CONDITION ZERO Cs 1.6 with graphical improvements and bot mode.GraphicsSame as CS but a few improvements. New player model 1 for each team. Slight improvements to weapons and such. But This is 2004 And Halflife 2 came out about the same time with the source engine. BUT this is on Goldsrc engine for a game that was realeased in 2004. AI: 8/10 Has a "Campaign" which is basically matches against bots where you try to complete goals like"Kill 4 enemys""Rescue 2 Hostages""use a Flashbang"Makes a nice Practice mode for singleplayer because the original CS didnt come with bots. The enemy AI is quite good if you arent a CS Pro and I had to reapet level quite a few times. Sound: 6/10Slight Improvements but overall the sameGameplay: 8/10Same As the original counter strike but i feel the hitboxes are a bit bigger. Recoil is still there so Spray-and-Pray isnt the way to go.Overall 7/10Decent Game Dont buy it on its own get it with CS:Complete Pack or the original Counter StrikeGame Design 6/10Pretty Good. Improvements across the board. Overall 7/10Only buy this with CS:Complete Set. Or with CS 1.6 Multiplayer is Mostly Dead. COUNTER STRIKE CONDITON ZERO : DELETED SCENESExpansion Pack For CS:CZ With a new campaign thats exactly like your average COD campaign WITH ZERO PLOT. I dont know why they made this because CS:S was almost finished and HL2 was hot stuff.Graphics: 6/10Same As CS:CZ and new enemy player models for the campaign. Not much to say here Sound 5/10Same as CS:CZ but some nice (and awful) music.AI: 4/10TERRIBLE the enemy ai in the campaign basically cycles from Run at you, Shoot you, Run away, RepeatEnemys have no strategy at all and Require no tactics to defeat unlike CS 1.6/CS:CZ. The only thing diffucult is when enemys respawn 2 seconds after you kill them. You dont make a game where enemys respawn after killing them to make up for there diffuculty. Game play 5/10Nothing New.Game Design: 6/10Levels are varied like a stealth mission and such but nothing special. No new weapons. Nothing specialOverall 5/10I dont know why the released this instead of CS:S.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												This game is all about the mission and the offline campaign that was created with it, called the "Condition Zero: Deleted Scenes". It was way easier than 1.6, headshots and spray kills happens way easier than in 1.6, and whereas some spam points has been removed in the old maps (and in the added CZ maps), it doesn't really change the layout all that much. It's still the same game - just easier, imo. I don't recommend it, since the campaign is dull and boring, gameplay answers to 1.6, just easier, as previously mentioned, and lastly, the "Call of Duty" offline bot campaign is so boring and repetitive, you might want to just beat expert, never to come back. It's that terrible. Buy 1.6 instead if you want the game in it's entirety, because CZ, while Source added some new elements and better graphics, is just a blatant copy with extra features thrown in there, for people who doesn't care.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Condition Zero comes with 2 modules:1. Condition Zero (CZ) - Provides a slightly different MP experience to that of CS1.6, mostly graphical changes with a few gameplay changes. Also has a player vs. bots singleplayer mode, which is essentially just multiplayer with bots instead of humans, but with added objectives to make it a bit more difficult.2. Deleted Scenes - A scripted single player campaign similar to something you'd see in Quake or Unreal Tournament.For simplicity's sake I'll go over the changes CZ introduces, just keep in mind this isn't something I've thoroughly researched or anything of the sort, just what I know from playing multiple versions of CS for around a decade now. If you don't know the core gameplay of Counter Strike to understand these changes... well then go buy 1.6 and then consider picking up CZ.ChangesLighting - Lighting is updated to be more smooth and natural, shadows and darkness is generally not as harsh and saturation looks much more natural, in my opinion this is a good change both aesthetically and gameplay wise, excluding the saturation change. I would prefer deeper saturation to make things easier to see and more colorful. You can somewhat counteract this by using a setting called digital vibrance in the NVidia control panel. If you have an AMD card they have a similar setting, though I do not know what it is called.Gun Models - Gun models are updated to look more realistic and metallic, most have changed color palettes or just added color in general and a select few have new animation, mostly just moving parts, for instance the bolt on the FAMAS/Clarion now moves when firing. Also the knife has a new animation which I think looks awful. Overall this is a positive change though.Character Models - Character models are completely changed. They are higher resolution but in my opinion the new models look lame in comparison to the 1.6 models.Textures - Pretty much every texture on the maps have been changed and made higher resolution. For the most part the changes are welcome to me, though they do effect the visual feel of the maps a little. I think I'd consider this a positive change.Outside of the additions I mentioned at the beginning of the review, that's really the extent of the changes. Mostly all visual changes.So the question is... do these changes warrant a purchase? Not in the slightest. For various reasons, if you're buying this for multiplayer, you're better off just playing 1.6.In my eyes, the only reason to pick up CZ is for the Deleted Scenes. However I don't believe Deleted Scenes is actually worth the $10 CZ goes for.Basically the campaign is a collection of missions with no overarching story or really anything of interest in the way of plot. They are all linear. They take place in different locales around the world. They are all played on the CT side, although the factions will differ. They offer a very small amount of puzzle solving. They have boss fights. They have forced stealth sections.Here is what I dislike about Deleted Scenes:Linear as hell, wouldn't be a problem if it didn't give you the illusion of choice with multiple hallways and doors just leading to dead ends, often without an item reward.Secrets are hidden pretty lazily and without thought, even when you go out of your way to look for them you probably won't find a majority of them, and when you do find them, they are mostly useless.Enemy placement has very little thought, often times they are placed in dark corners or closed doors. If they are placed somewhere that requires a scripted animation, they are completely invincible until the animation plays out.Boss battles are awful, all of them but the final 2 bosses are insanely easy. The 2nd to last boss is just a bullet sponge that can take literally several AK clips to the head and numerous grenades before he dies, but he can kill you just as quick as any other enemy, not to mention he's surrounded by 2 shot kill snipers AND you are on a timelimit to kill him. Just awful. The last boss is actually pretty good and a satisfying finale, but he also has 2 bullet sponge troops that will kick your♥♥♥♥♥if you don't cheese them somehow.The game is incredibly easy, even on hard. The only time I was challenged was the aforementioned bosses and when I had to escort the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ AI.Escorting AI is just plain awful.The most fun guns run out of ammo quickly.You can get trapped by AI very easily.Some puzzles are very difficult not because they require you to use your brain but rather because they require you to go around knifing random things (MULTIPLE TIMES) until something breaks, and it's rarely obvious what you should be attacking.Allied AI is uselessEnemy AI is braindead. Most of the time they just stand in one spot and shoot at you, never trying to get to a better position.The forced stealth is AWFUL. It's dreadfully boring and boils down to crouching behind a box, waiting for enemy to turn back, moving to next box, waiting for enemy to turn back, rinse, repeat, rinse, repeat, over and over again and it always left me wanting to just quit playing it was so boring and uninspired. More guns, less sneaking. PLEASE.With that said, I think Deleted Scenes is a fairly average FPS when it's at it's best. When at it's worst it is just plain bad. Unless you're a die hard CS fan that wants to experience it, there are so many other games to spend your time and money on.Oh and I didn't even mention the fact that this came out in 2004. Half Life 2 came out 7 months after this. Take a second to think about that.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												Boring... Just boring, since I'm neither a really dedicated CS gamer, nor am I really good at FPS games, maybe I'm not the right to judge.The AI is not really good, and sometimes buggy, some enemies didn't even bother shooting at me, while other just hat lightning reflexes. That doesn't matter, because even on Medium the enemies bullets don't really do any damage. The same applies to your bullets, but since you got about 2 seconds time to aim, you can simply do all headshots, which kinda works.Ammunition is always a problem, which adds some kind of difficulty to the game, since you are forced to engage close combat with sniper rifles and long range combats with shotguns, just keep one mag an a long range weapon and it shouldn't be a problem.The grafics are like Condition Zero grafics, not fancy nowadays, but better than CS1.6 and are well enough.The main reason I dislike this game is the complete lack of any story. There were some minor "plot" - like parts, where you are told why to go there and kill all those guys, or sometimes sneek past the guards you could easily overwhelm. Another thing is the sometimes really hard to find routes through the level, some pathways are blocked by a locked door, others by invisible walls, and the worst kind are the pathways, which actually are blocked by some kind of fence, which you are supposed to climb over, but you are never given any hint to do that.All in all it is a training program for CS: Condition Zero and maybe some other counter strike games, but does not really have any motivational aspects for me.

number of helpful: 5 of 16 people (31%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												One of the buggiest games I've ever played. It seems a joke. These are the reasons to not buy this game ever:1. Very repetitive2. Non sense puzzles to solve to make the game last longer: Stupid like a switch does not work until you kill an enemy that is hidden somewhere.3. Everything is scripted: Sometimes there is friendly fire and sometimes not, some enemies can be killed with barrels some not, enemies will teleport infront of you.4. Very poorly scripted: NPC can block your pass to finish a mission so you have to load a previous save to finish a mission. NPC are ridicously exposed so they can be killed and missin fails.5. Very buggy: Sometimes you cant climb a ladder or sometimes you have to load a previous save because something that was supossed to happen didn't happened.6. No realism at all: Things like killing bosses with 5 headshots with an sniper rifle, enemies shooting behind bushes where you cannot see through, enemies shooting you in darkness, etc.7. Really poor difficulty level: I played in hard mode. The first missions were just fine in difficultie but for some reason, the more I played, the more overclocked the enemies are: yes, overclocked. Enemies will run faster, shoot faster and need 3 headshots to be killed. The last mission I played (in japan) was so ridiculous that enemies could kill you in 1ms after you cross a wall, or walk 30 meters in 1 second, just like the first half life ninjas but with bigger guns.8. The saves are broken: I've never seen this in my life. The save files have two major bugs. The first one is that each time you load a save file, your weapon starts firing until you switch weapon. This makes you loose a lot of ammo. The second bug is that when you load a file, you dont appear exactly were you should be and you dont have the same ammo and health. Actually I got stuck in a situation where I was appearing in front an enemy who killed me in 1 millisecond after loading.

number of helpful: 13 of 33 people (39%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												One of the worst FPS games I've ever played. Weapons feel terrible and behave very differently compared to the multi-player versions of those exact same weapons. AI is horrible. Visuals are decent for a game running on top of the goldsrc engine but at the same time visuals are not very optimised causing slowdowns now and then. Sounds and music are low quality stuff. Voice acting is ridiculously bad. There are plenty of issues to talk about. But all this is mostly forgivable stuff.Why you might ask? It's because of the mess that is the development history of this game. It was originally conceived in 2000. It was announced in 2001 at E3. However the studio that started the development, Rogue Entertainment, went defunct later that year. The development was then handed over to Gearbox Software but they were not allowed to complete this game after missing out the 2002 deadline. Then the bits and pieces were sticked together in a rush by Ritual Entertainment in 2003 but that work was for naught. It's a miracle that CS:CZ was even released at all. The fourth studio to work with this game, the newly founded Turtle Rock Studios, abandoned the whole single-player campaign to make their own thing. CS:CZ was eventually released in 2004 as a multi-player focused training game with bots.


Precursor to modern military shooters: Player cannot progress before scripted cutscene ends and NPC opens a door in Middle East scenario. 
A Screenshot of Counter-Strike: Condition Zero Deleted Scenes
By: Dekonega




CS:CZ:DS offers a curious peek into the future of what could have been. More refined version of CS:CZ:DS is what the grand single-player Counter-Strike game should have been. Instead we got a campaign about series of matches against bots with challenges in CS:CZ. That's all fine and dandy but that isn't very interesting. What's interesting about CS:CZ:DS is that here we have a game, that's more of a precursor to Call of Duty, and a game that has a lot in common with the Call of Duty: Modern Warfare games, and other "Modern Military Shooters" in-general.


What's with the terrorists always attacking Russian nuclear missile facilities? 
A Screenshot of Counter-Strike: Condition Zero Deleted Scenes
By: Dekonega




CS:CZ:DS is a long pipe FPS, that features series of disconnected missions, extremely heavy scripting, NPC interaction similar to the Call of Duty, similarly boring repetitive gunplay, vehicle battles against Hind helicopter, explosions, terrorists launching nukes from old Soviet missile silos, and all the other stuff except the high quality craftsmanship that goes into the Call of Duty games.I bought the game when it was originally released in 2004 and it was pretty bad even then. I just installed CS:CZ to replay it since it was release for Linux in 2013 and I'm mostly spending my time in Linux thesedays. The CS:CZ:DS can be an interesting precursor for the modern military shooters if you're interested in playing that kind of stuff but in-generally people should avoid this game for what it is. It's an unfinished single-player Counter-Strike game that features normal Counter-Strike multi-player mode with slightly updated graphics and bots.


This guy is playing a game about cops and terrorists at police station where cops are about to have a meeting about terrorists. 
A Screenshot of Counter-Strike: Condition Zero Deleted Scenes
By: Dekonega

number of helpful: 4 of 14 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												DELETED SCENES:-Really Repetitive-As stereotypical as it gets-Extremely predictable campaign-Poorly made models (such as not being able to shoot through transparent bits)-Boss fights (yes, boss fights) have ridiculous health. One took like 20 head-shots to kill him (no joke).-No real story, just missions-Recoil is almost like Call Of Duty, all bullets go perfectly straightNORMAL:+Great for beginners-No story, just the same old 1.6Overall, Deleted Scenes is awful. If you are new to Counter-Strike, then the normal Condition Zero would be great for you. However, if you are already play CS, then this game is not for you.Believe me, the campaign from Deleted Scenes is not worth playing at all.

												Downvoted only due to the following:The practice of paying for mods is antithetical to the nature of the modding community; an optional "DONATION" button is not (Just like on the Nexus http://www.nexusmods.com/skyrim/? ). Was a fun game, The fact that Valve is doing this and that Bethesda is endorsing it and they both taking the largest share of the modders' work is American Corporate greed at it's finest.Take something artistic and done for the love of the subject matter, monetize it, then allow the accountants to define art as widgets, and then creativity is now run by the mercantile class, the middle men, who are "America Corporates".If they had any integrity and decency, any moneys brought in, at the very least, should be 100% donated to charities on behalf off the modding community in conjunction with Valve or Bethesda or whomever. See Gaben, you don't need the cash grab, you can win by getting good press which in the long run would do better for you to show you are not like EA et al.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2013
												This recommendation is for Condition Zero: Deleted Scenes.What can I say, other than it's basically Call of Duty made with the GoldSRC engine.It doesn't look good, animations are clunky, it usually takes enemies two or three headshots to die (seriously) and the stealth parts can get really annoying.Even with that, it managed to keep me entertained long enough to actually finish it, but in short bursts. I don't think anyone will find themselves playing this game for more than 40 minutes or so at a time.I give it a 6 / 10 only because I finished it and because FPSs are one of my favourite genres of gaming, but if you're not into FPSs I'm pretty sure you'll give it a lower score.5-word summary:GoldSRC wasn't meant to CoD.

												Counter-Strike: Condition Zero. Where to start? First off,  let me just say that you would be better off getting CSS or CS:GO (CS:GO gets hated on way too much). Now, Condition Zero does not have the best graphics. By that, I mean the graphics are terrible and the animation is equally bad. Condition Zero also has a terrible map. For someone who has never played Counter Strike, it might be fine. But for someone who has—well, let's just say that you would be better off spending your $10 on something else.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												As dated as this game may be, compared to Global Offensive. Condition Zero is a mainly singleplayer focused Counter Strike title oddly enough. Which its the very old unreal style campaign, not the story driven one we now see in a regualr shooter. So; is it as fun as newer Counter Strike titles? Yes, maybe even a bit more. Has it aged well? No. It a very love hate relationship between me and the campaign style here. I like the ai team mate selection gimmick, allowing you to choose better, people to be with assuming you have the right points to buy them before the match begins. The stat's on them which are skill, co-op, and bravery actually matter and can have very noticable effects on how they move around the map. Me, I personally think Travis, the riot shield weilding badass of 300 confirmed kills is someone that is a required team mate. Where as one may go with Pete someone who as balanced stats across the board, but only has a smg. There is actually a pretty good amount of tactical feel to this, as many times I was stuck on a level I could switch out team mates and DESTROY. BUt this campaign style is a little.......... frustrating? In each match there are a certain preset requirements for you to complete. These are the BAIN OF COUNTER STRIKE, as some on the expert difficulty are masochistically made. Kill and enemy with a knife and survive the round? ♥♥♥♥ no. Besides that, I recommend this game. Also shotguns are much better in source.

												Counter-Strike: Condition Zero. Where to start? First off,  let me just say that you would be better off getting CSS or CS:GO (CS:GO gets hated on way too much). Now, Condition Zero does not have the best graphics. By that, I mean the graphics are terrible and the animation is equally bad. Condition Zero also has a terrible map. For someone who has never played Counter Strike, it might be fine. But for someone who has—well, let's just say that you would be better off spending your $10 on something else.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												A suprisingly good game. The game looks extremely dated, and looks like its not worth it, but the game is actually very fun. The game is basically counter-strike, execpt with a single player "Tour of Duty", or actual somewhat campaign in deleted scenes' case. Cause the review is taking me to Condition Zero, the regular version, even though I wanted to just talk about the Deleted Scenes, I will talk about both. So yeah, the big thing about this game is that you have a single player mode. The version in the regular version is a "Tour of Duty", which is just doing the bomb or hostage games with bots on both sides, with a few missions you have to complete before the game ends. While this just sounds like something that should have been a update for regular Couter-Strike, it actually throws in some great ideas. Like being able to select who you want to be on your team. Each character takes up a certain amount of points, meaning you cant select them all willy nilly, and they come with individual stats and weapons. These stats include, bravery (how willing they are to fight), skill (how well they are at aiming), and coop (the chance that they will listen to your commands). Thats another cool mechanic, you can talk to your teammates with the voice command buttons, and they will listen...sometimes. They also have free will so that they can ethier say "No" because they can't, or because they don't want to, making sure that you choose your teammates wisely. In Deleted Scenes, instead of "Tour of Duty", you instead have various situations that have cutscenes, listed objectives that change as you go, and only certain weapons for each situations. This adds alot more variety to the game, and makes playing each individual missions worth it. And thats really it for the games. I can't review the multiplayer since I can't find a server. I say that if ya have some left over money and need something to do, buy these games, if ya can only buy one, get Deleted scenes.Review Score:Condition Zero-7.5/10Deleted Scene-8.5/10

												Hi people, I just thougth I'd write a recommendation for this epic early 2000 game. So you play as different factions from the original Counter-Strike from 1998 but with updated graphics and infact new models. The game has AI that attempts to look at you making you think that the AI likes you.. Then they run at you with a machete, and don't forget how you are ALWAYS alone even though you saw 5 swat guys behind you  1 min ago. So, this game in a nutshell: Lone wolf, cool, time killer and something you  can play without stopping. It's not like you get stuck in Sierras obvious traps and puzzles. I also recommend you to YouTube it, because a video is always better than words! (♥♥♥♥ you) have an awesome friggin day.. (that was for me) enjoy DS.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												Counter-Strike is a first-person shooter in which players join either the terrorist team, the counter-terrorist team, or become spectators. Each team attempts to complete their mission objective and/or eliminate the opposing team. Each round starts with the two teams spawning simultaneously.A player can choose to play as one of eight different default character models (four for each side, although Counter-Strike: Condition Zero added two extra models, bringing the total to ten). Players are generally given a few seconds before the round begins (known as "freeze time") to prepare and buy equipment, during which they cannot attack or move (one notable exception is that a player may receive damage during freeze time. This happens when a map is changed to spawn players at a certain height above the ground, thus causing fall damage to the player. This is a method map designers use to alter the starting "HP" of players on a map). They can return to the buy area within a set amount of time to buy more equipment (some custom maps included neutral "buy zones" that could be used by both teams). Once the round has ended, surviving players retain their equipment for use in the next round; players who were killed begin the next round with the basic default starting equipment.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 28, 2015
												The leading Counter Strike game when compared to CS:CZ and Counter Strike. This game has a proper storyline which is absent from all other counter strike games, even CS:GO. The storyline is realistic, immersive and diversifed in the world of espionage and counter terrorism across all nations and offers a non-biased perspective of terrorism: that terrorism has no race, nationality or religion and shows the the world can be united against extremism across all fronts: from Lithuania to Russia and from the Middle East to the USA and the Philippines. The player is exposed to hostage, IED, sieges and other crisises in bank robberies, to sieges of nuclear and oil production facilities all over the world, in some cases functioning as a mirror image of actual crisises that occured for instance the US bank heist and the Philippines German hostage crisis following the plane terrorist incident and the embassy crisis in Teheran, Iran. The game was noticably founded on the tenets of the aforementioned and was shaped into a realistic, acceptable storyline given events worldwide at the time aided the understanding of the storyline as well, enhancing the cognitive ability to accept the storyline exposed to the player. This game is one of the few games that capitalises on the aforementioned. If it wern't for the graphics, this game would still be played as much as Insurgency or CS:GO today, by projection. Despite the Half Life engine leading to constraints on aesthetics due to the limitations of the physics laws in half life, it is still a must play. It's an eye opener to the world of terrorism and extremism still revelant today as it encompasses incidents from the 90s to the 2000s.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												Regarding CS CZ DELETED SCENES. A very solid mod. Offers great missions, voices and sounds are great. Mission crossover with normal CS maps. Realistic accuracy and gun control, not the reatrded♥♥♥♥♥♥show from normal CS where it feelsl like everyone is shooting drunk. Challenging gameplay with good mechanics and a few new things added. Highly recomend to any halflife player, aspecially to CS players to get the feel how CS really should have been.Finally after the beating the stock campaign matches on all difficulties and having played some online, the game is fairly simple and similar to original CS, just more polished. Good game overall, but not for my taste. Luck in this game has a bigger role than skill, and a game mechanic like that is unappealing to selfaware FPS gamer. I can beat UT2004 on Godlike, yet this is almost impossible for me. A good game, but not my game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												Ah, Condition Zero. The red-headed stepchild of the Counter-Strike world.Pity that, it's a really good game.   Since I have a damaged computer at the moment, with limited 3d accel.  I can'trun Source-engine games.   This one uses the original Half-Life/Counter-Strike mod's Goldsrc.This version is a bit nicer than CS 1.6, and is quite a bit more polished.   There is some activity on the servers, if you're into multiplayer.  The maps are quite nice-looking for a old quake-engine game.  The included versions of Cobblestone and Aztec look great are a blast to play.I got it as part of a bundle, and it's been one of the best buys I've made on Steam.   Absolutely recommend.(don't get me wrong, CS:GO is great, but don't pass this one up because it's old).   For n00bs, its a great intro to theCS world.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												This is a unique twist on the Counter-Strike formula. Instead of focusing on multiplayer, this game is based on single player gameplay. You must fight in multiple locations, hire other Counter Terrorists with reputation, and complete missions in the middle of the game. Think of operation missions in Counter-Strike Global Offensive, but ones that can be completed in one match. I for one enjoy this different style of gameplay.
